BUSINESS.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - BUSINESS section in bullet points:

• Coinbase holds customer assets one-to-one at all times and does not act on customer assets without customer consent.

• The company offers products and services to three customer groups: consumers, institutions, and developers.

• Transaction fees for consumer trading include volume-based transaction fees and a spread depending on the type of trade.

• Simple trading fees are generally higher than advanced trading fees due to the typical nature of transactions and unique benefits of each offering.

• Coinbase Prime is a full-service prime brokerage platform designed for institutional customers.

Note: I've excluded any information that is not a concrete fact, such as mission statements or product descriptions. Let me know if you'd like me to add anything else!

RISK FACTORS.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART I - RISK FACTORS section in bullet points:

* The market price of COIN's Class A common stock could decline, and you could lose part or all of your investment due to various risks.
* Our operating results have significantly fluctuated, including due to the highly volatile nature of crypto, with fluctuations occurring from quarter to quarter in accordance with market sentiments and movements in the broader cryptoeconomy.
* Crypto asset trading activity, including trading volume and prevailing trading prices for crypto assets, can be highly volatile.
* The company's ability to attract, maintain, grow, and engage its customer and developer base is a significant risk factor.
* Changes in the legislative or regulatory environment, or actions by U.S. or foreign governments or regulators, can impact the company's operations.
* Regulatory changes or scrutiny that impact the company's ability to offer certain products or services are a risk factor.
* The company's mix of revenue between transaction and subscription and services is a significant risk factor.
* Pricing for or temporary suspensions of the company's products and services can be a risk.
* Adding crypto assets to, or removing from, the platform can be a risk.
* The company's ability to establish and maintain partnerships, collaborations, joint ventures, or strategic alliances with third parties is a risk factor.
* Market conditions of, and overall sentiment towards, the cryptoeconomy are a significant risk factor.
* Macroeconomic conditions, including interest rates, inflation, and instability in the global banking system, can impact the company's operations.
* Adverse legal proceedings or regulatory enforcement actions can be a risk factor.
* The development and introduction of existing and new products and services by competitors can be a risk.
* System failures, outages or interruptions, including with respect to the platform and third-party crypto networks, can be a risk.
* The company's lack of control over decentralized or third-party blockchains and networks that may experience downtime, cyberattacks,

ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY section in bullet points:

• COIN's primary cybersecurity oversight responsibility is shared by its board of directors, audit and compliance committee (Audit Committee), and senior management.
• The company's cybersecurity risk management program is integrated into its overall enterprise risk management program.
• COIN has a defined procedure for timely incident detection, containment, response, and remediation, including a written security incident response plan.
• The company conducts annual cybersecurity and privacy training of employees, including incident response personnel and senior management.
• COIN uses external consultants or third-party experts to assess, test, or assist with aspects of its cybersecurity controls as needed.
• The company has not identified material risks from known cybersecurity threats in the past fiscal year that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to affect its operations, business strategy, operating results, or financial condition.

ITEM 2. PROPERTIES.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 2. PROPERTIES section:

• The company is a remote-first organization, allowing most employees to work remotely for the vast majority of roles.
• Substantially all executive team meetings are held virtually, with occasional in-person meetings at locations outside of offices or distributed around the world.
• All stockholder meetings are held virtually.
• The company does not maintain a headquarters but leases physical offices in select major cities in the US and other countries for collaboration and team building.
• The company believes its current facilities will meet its needs for the immediate future.

ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT’S COMMON E.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT’S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES in bullet points:

• Our Class A common stock began trading on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol “COIN” on April 14, 2021.
• As of February 6, 2025, there were 263 registered holders of record of our Class A common stock and 8 registered holders of record of our Class B common stock.
• We have never declared or paid cash dividends on our capital stock and do not anticipate paying any dividends in the foreseeable future.
• The cumulative total return to stockholders of our Class A common stock between April 14, 2021, and December 31, 2024, was compared to the Nasdaq Composite Index, the Nasdaq U.S. Benchmark Financial Services Index, the S&P North American Technology Index, and the price of Bitcoin.
• The graph assumes an investment of $100 in our Class A common stock at the closing sale price of $328.28 per share on April 14, 2021.
• We did not repurchase any shares of our Class A common stock during the three months ended December 31, 2024.

ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANAL.summary:
Here are the key facts from the MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS section in bullet points:

• For the year ended December 31, 2024, Coinbase's net revenue was $6.3 billion, including $4.0 billion in transaction revenue and $2.3 billion in subscription and services revenue.
• For the year ended December 31, 2023, Coinbase's net revenue was $2.9 billion, including $1.5 billion in transaction revenue and $1.4 billion in subscription and services revenue.
• For the year ended December 31, 2024, Coinbase's net income was $2.6 billion.
• For the year ended December 31, 2023, Coinbase's net income was $0.1 billion.
• For the year ended December 31, 2024, Coinbase's Adjusted EBITDA was $3.3 billion.
• For the year ended December 31, 2023, Coinbase's Adjusted EBITDA was $1.0 billion.
• In 2025, Coinbase expects technology and development expenses to grow modestly in the first quarter compared to the fourth quarter of 2024, primarily due to headcount growth and variable infrastructure and customer support expenses.
• In 2025, Coinbase expects sales and marketing expenses to grow compared to the fourth quarter of 2024, primarily due to expected higher USDC rewards expense and variable non-brand marketing spend.

Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Di.summary:
Here are the key facts from the Equity investment risk section in bullet points:

• The company utilizes the asset and liability method for computing income tax provision.
• Deferred tax assets and liabilities reflect expected future consequences of temporary differences between financial reporting and tax bases, using enacted tax rates.
• The valuation allowance is established when it is more likely than not that deferred tax assets will not be recovered from future taxable income.
• The company recognizes the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not the position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities.
• Interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits are recognized within the provision for income taxes.
• Crypto asset transactions are treated under the same tax principles as property transactions, with gains or losses recognized in the amount of the difference between fair market value and tax basis.
• The company records a liability when it is probable that a loss has been incurred and the amount is reasonably estimable, involving significant judgment.
• Legal proceedings and claims are recorded when it is probable that a loss will be incurred and the amount is reasonably estimable.

ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DI.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK:

• The Federal Reserve raised the Federal Funds Rate from under 0.1% as of March 2022 to a peak of 5.33% from July 2023 to September 2024, followed by declines to arrive at 4.33% as of December 31, 2024.

• There was an increase of over 500 basis points in the Federal Funds Rate between December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2024.

• A hypothetical 200 basis points increase or decrease in average interest rates applied to our average month-end cash equivalents balances for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023 would have resulted in an impact of $165.8 million and $122.9 million, respectively, on interest earned.

• A hypothetical 200 basis points increase or decrease in average interest rates applied to daily USDC reserve balances held by Circle for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023 would have resulted in an impact of $387.8 million and $294.2 million, respectively, on stablecoin revenue.

• The fair value of our cash and cash equivalents and customer custodial funds would not be significantly affected by either an increase or a decrease in interest rates due to our investment policy and strategy to preserve capital and meet liquidity requirements without increasing risk.

ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEM.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA as bullet points:

• The financial statements of Coinbase Global, Inc. were audited by an independent registered public accounting firm.
• The audit was conducted in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB).
• The auditor expressed an opinion on the financial statements, stating that they present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company as of December 31, 2024, and 2023.
• The auditor also audited the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024, and expressed an unqualified opinion on it.
• The audit included evaluating the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the financial statements.
• Crypto assets held in cold storage were identified as a critical audit matter, requiring special attention due to their materiality and complexity.

CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES section in bullet points:

• The company's disclosure controls and procedures are designed to ensure accurate and timely reporting under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
• As of December 31, 2024, the company's management concluded that its disclosure controls and procedures were effective at a reasonable assurance level.
• The company's internal control over financial reporting was evaluated as of December 31, 2024, based on the criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013).
• The effectiveness of the company's internal control over financial reporting was audited by Deloitte & Touche LLP and reported in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
• There were no changes to the company's internal control over financial reporting during the most recently completed fiscal quarter that have materially affected its effectiveness.
• The effectiveness of any system of internal control over financial reporting is subject to inherent limitations, including the exercise of judgment and the inability to eliminate misconduct completely.

ITEM 9B. OTHER INFORMATION.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - ITEM 9B. OTHER INFORMATION in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, three of the Company's officers adopted a Rule 10b5-1 Plan: Emilie Choi (President and Chief Operating Officer), Jennifer Jones (Chief Accounting Officer), and an unnamed officer.
• The Choi Plan provided for the potential sale of up to 733,235 shares of Class A common stock between March 3, 2025, and December 31, 2025.
• The Jones Plan provided for the potential sale of up to 23,625 shares of Class A common stock between March 4, 2025, and February 27, 2026.
• As of the date of termination of the Choi Plan (December 17, 2024), Ms. Choi had not sold any shares of Class A common stock thereunder.
• The number of shares to be withheld or mandatorily sold by the Company upon future vesting events could only be determined upon the occurrence of future events.
• The numbers of shares (i) to be received by Ms. Jones upon the future grant, vesting, and settlement of RSUs for shares of Class A common stock and (ii) to be withheld or mandatorily sold by the Company or sold pursuant to the Prior Jones Plan can only be determined upon the occurrence of future events.
• The Choi Plan provided for the sale of shares of Class A common stock to be received upon the future vesting and settlement of certain outstanding RSUs, net of any shares withheld or mandatorily sold by the Company to satisfy applicable tax obligations.

ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS A.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CORPORATE GOVERNANCE in bullet points:

• The Company's definitive Proxy Statement for its 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders will be filed with the SEC no later than 120 days after December 31, 2024.
• A copy of the Company’s Insider Trading Policy is filed with this Annual Report on Form 10-K as Exhibit 19.1.

ITEM 15. EXHIBITS AND FINANCIAL STATEMEN.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART IV - ITEM 15. EXHIBITS AND FINANCIAL STATEMENT SCHEDULES in bullet points:

• The following financial statements are included in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K: Reports of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm, Consolidated Balance Sheets, Consolidated Statements of Operations, Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income (Loss), Consolidated Statements of Changes in Stockholders’ Equity, and Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.

• All financial statement schedules have been omitted due to the required information being included in the consolidated financial statements or notes thereto, or because it is not required.

• The following exhibits are filed as part of this Annual Report on Form 10-K: 
  † Indicates a management or compensatory plan or arrangement in which directors or executive officers are eligible to participate.
  * Portions of some exhibits have been omitted as permitted under Item 601(b)(10)(iv) of Regulation S-K, and will be furnished to the SEC upon request.

• The Registrant agrees to furnish supplementally a copy of omitted schedules and exhibits to the SEC upon request.
